question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of now, Mike Pence has announced his candidacy for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, but he faces significant competition from other candidates, including Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley, among others. Trump's strong base and previous presidency give him a considerable advantage in the primaries, and he remains a leading figure in the Republican Party. Pence's support seems to be limited compared to Trump's, and he has not shown the same level of traction in polls or fundraising. Furthermore, the dynamics of the Republican primaries can shift significantly as the election date approaches, but current indicators suggest that Pence is unlikely to secure the nomination. Therefore, I estimate the probability of Pence being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election to be quite low.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee and Mike Pence not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (a) Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Mike Pence is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my last knowledge update in October 2023, the political landscape for the 2024 Republican primary is still evolving, with several prominent candidates, including Ted Cruz and Mike Pence, vying for the nomination. Ted Cruz has a solid base of support within the Republican Party and has previously run for president, which could bolster his chances of securing the nomination again. However, Mike Pence, as the former Vice President, also has significant influence and support among certain factions within the party. The dynamics of the race will depend on various factors, including the candidates' campaign strategies, public opinion, and the outcomes of the primaries and caucuses leading up to the convention. Given that both candidates have a chance to gain traction, it is difficult to predict with certainty who will emerge as the nominee. While Cruz has a strong chance, Pence's presence in the race complicates the scenario. If we consider the historical context and the current political climate, it seems plausible that Cruz could be the nominee, but Pence's non-nomination is less certain. Therefore, I would estimate a moderate probability of this question resolving as YES, reflecting the uncertainty and competitiveness of the Republican primary.

question.title: Will either Mike Pence or Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Mike Pence or Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of now, both Mike Pence and Ted Cruz are prominent figures within the Republican Party and have previously held significant positions (Pence as Vice President and Cruz as a Senator). However, the political landscape can change rapidly, especially with the emergence of new candidates and shifting voter sentiments. As of my last knowledge update in October 2023, both Pence and Cruz have been part of discussions regarding the 2024 nomination, but their popularity and support within the party may fluctuate leading up to the convention. Additionally, other candidates could emerge and gain traction, potentially overshadowing Pence and Cruz. Given the uncertainty and the competitive nature of the primary elections, while there is a reasonable chance that either Pence or Cruz could secure the nomination, it's also quite possible that they may not. Therefore, I would estimate a moderate probability that either of them becomes the nominee.

question.body:

Given the current state of the Republican primary landscape and the strength of Trump's position, I estimate a high probability that Trump will be the nominee and Haley will not.

question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and Nikki Haley not be the nominee?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Nikki Haley is not selected as the nominee. If both conditions are met, the question resolves as **Yes**; otherwise, it resolves as **No**.

This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To evaluate the likelihood of Glenn Youngkin being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election while Nikki Haley is not, we need to consider several factors. 1. **Current Political Landscape**: As of now, both Youngkin and Haley have been prominent figures in the Republican Party, with Youngkin gaining attention due to his governorship in Virginia and Haley having served as the U.N. Ambassador and Governor of South Carolina. Their political profiles suggest they are both viable candidates. 2. **Polling and Support**: Polls leading up to the primaries will play a significant role in determining the nominee. If Youngkin maintains or increases his support among Republican voters while Haley's support wanes, the scenario becomes more plausible. As of my last data in 2023, Youngkin has been seen as a rising star within the party, while Haley has also garnered significant support. 3. **Delegate Dynamics**: The Republican National Convention is influenced by a series of primaries and caucuses. If Youngkin performs well in early states, he could secure a substantial number of delegates, making it more likely for him to become the nominee. Conversely, if Haley performs well, it could complicate Youngkin's path. 4. **Potential Candidates**: The possibility of other candidates entering the race could also affect this outcome. If a strong candidate emerges who takes votes away from either Youngkin or Haley, it could change the dynamics. 5. **Historical Context**: Looking at previous Republican nominations, it is common for multiple candidates to compete fiercely, leading to unexpected outcomes. However, if Youngkin can consolidate support and Haley's support diminishes, the conditions for a YES resolution become more favorable. Considering these factors, while it is possible for Youngkin to be the nominee and Haley not to be, the political landscape is dynamic and uncertain, making it difficult to assign a very high probability to this outcome.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Joe Biden dying before Saturday, July 27, 2024, it's essential to consider several factors. Joe Biden, as of my last knowledge update, is the President of the United States and is under constant medical supervision and care. While no one can predict death with certainty, the likelihood of a sudden death announcement is generally low for public figures who are receiving regular health assessments. Additionally, Biden's age and health conditions might be factors to consider, but there has been no significant indication of imminent health crises leading to death. Given these considerations, the probability of an official announcement of his death before market close on Friday, July 26, 2024, is likely very low.

question.title: Will Joe Biden remain President through the end of July 2024 and not die before Saturday, July 26th, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Joe Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (Eastern Time). This means he does not resign, die, or otherwise cease to be President before then. A temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment, making his VP the Acting President, does not cause a NO resolution as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution. (b) There is no official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. If both conditions are satisfied, the question resolves YES. If either or both conditions are not satisfied, the question resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 and not dying before July 26, 2024, we need to consider several factors. 1. Political Stability: As of my last knowledge update in October 2023, Joe Biden was serving as President and had not indicated any plans to resign. Political circumstances can change, but unless there is a significant event (like a major scandal or health issue), it is likely he will remain in office. 2. Health Considerations: Joe Biden is the oldest sitting president in U.S. history, and concerns about his health have been a topic of discussion. However, as of October 2023, he was actively fulfilling his duties and had not shown any public signs of imminent health decline. While age does increase the risk of health issues, predicting specific events like death is inherently uncertain. 3. Historical Context: Historically, U.S. Presidents have completed their terms unless extraordinary circumstances arise. While there have been instances of Presidents resigning or passing away in office, they are relatively rare. 4. Temporary Transfers of Power: The scenario allows for the possibility of a temporary transfer of power without affecting the resolution of the question. This adds a layer of security to the YES outcome since even a temporary incapacitation would not trigger a NO resolution. 5. Timeframe: The timeframe until the end of July 2024 is relatively short, and while unforeseen events can happen, the likelihood of both conditions being met (remaining President and not dying) seems plausible based on current knowledge and trends. Considering these factors, I estimate that the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 and not dying before July 26, 2024, is reasonably high, though not without risk due to his age and health.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden dies before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, or (b) Joe Biden does not remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. (b) Joe Biden ceases to be the US President before the end of July 2024 (ET) due to resignation, death, or any other reason. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect the YES resolution for part (b). Otherwise, the question resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability of either (a) Joe Biden dying before July 26, 2024, or (b) him not remaining President through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors. 

1. **Health and Age**: Joe Biden was born on November 20, 1942, which makes him over 81 years old by July 2024. While age is a risk factor for health issues, predicting death is inherently uncertain. As of the latest data, he has been in relatively good health, but unforeseen health crises can occur.

2. **Political Landscape**: The likelihood of Joe Biden not remaining President through the end of July 2024 could stem from various scenarios, including resignation, impeachment, or other political upheavals. Given the political climate and the upcoming 2024 Presidential election, there is a chance that political pressures could lead to his resignation, especially if polls indicate a strong challenge or if significant scandals arise.

3. **Historical Precedent**: Historically, U.S. Presidents have faced various challenges that could lead to their departure from office, but outright death in office is rare. The last sitting president to die in office was John F. Kennedy in 1963. 

4. **Current Context**: As of now, there are no significant indicators suggesting that Biden is in immediate danger of death or that he is likely to resign. However, the political environment can change rapidly, and unexpected events can occur.

Taking these factors into account, while the possibility of either scenario cannot be completely ruled out, the probabilities of both occurring before the specified date seem relatively low. Therefore, I would estimate a modest probability for the question resolving YES.

Given the current dynamics, the probability that either Trump Jr. or Haley becomes the nominee is moderate, but the uncertainty surrounding Trump Jr.'s potential candidacy lowers the overall probability. Therefore, I estimate that the probability of either Donald Trump Jr. or Nikki Haley being the Republican nominee is around 0.4.

question.title: Will Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Vivek Ramaswamy being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider various factors including his current standing in the Republican party, polling data, endorsements, and competition from other candidates. As of my last update, Ramaswamy had gained some traction but was still a relatively new figure in the political landscape compared to established candidates like Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis. The Republican nomination process usually favors candidates with significant party support and established voter bases. Given that the Republican National Convention will occur in mid-2024, there is still considerable time for the political situation to evolve. Currently, while Ramaswamy has potential and could appeal to certain segments of the Republican electorate, it seems more likely that he will face strong competition from more established candidates. Thus, while it is not impossible for him to become the nominee, the probability of this happening is relatively low at this time.

question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and Vivek Ramaswamy not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (1) Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Vivek Ramaswamy is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To evaluate the probability of Mike Pence being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election while Vivek Ramaswamy is not, we need to consider several factors. 

1. **Current Political Landscape**: As of my last knowledge update in October 2023, Mike Pence has been a prominent figure in the Republican Party, having served as Vice President under Donald Trump. However, his popularity among the Republican base has waned since leaving office, especially with the rise of more populist candidates like Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis. 

2. **Vivek Ramaswamy's Position**: Vivek Ramaswamy has gained attention as a fresh face within the Republican field, positioning himself as an outsider appealing to the party's base. His campaign has been characterized by a strong focus on cultural issues and a pro-business stance, which resonates with a significant portion of the Republican electorate.

3. **Delegate Dynamics**: The nomination process at the Republican National Convention is heavily influenced by the delegates. If Pence is able to secure a substantial number of endorsements and support from key party figures, he could potentially consolidate enough delegate support. However, Ramaswamy's appeal to younger voters and his outsider status could complicate Pence's chances if he remains a strong contender.

4. **Historical Context**: Historically, the Republican Party has shown a tendency to nominate candidates who align closely with the party's base sentiments at the time of the convention. Given the current trends, it seems more likely that the party will lean towards candidates who embody the populist and anti-establishment sentiments that have been gaining traction.

Considering these factors, the likelihood of Pence being the nominee while Ramaswamy is not seems to be low. The competition within the party is fierce, and both candidates have their own bases of support. Thus, I would estimate a lower probability for this question resolving YES.

However, the political landscape is highly dynamic, and many factors can influence the outcome, including public opinion, campaign strategies, and the emergence of other candidates. Currently, Donald Trump appears to be the frontrunner in the Republican primaries, which could significantly reduce the chances of either Ramaswamy or Pence securing the nomination. While it's possible for either of them to gain traction and win the nomination, the likelihood seems lower given the current political context. Therefore, I estimate that the probability of either Vivek Ramaswamy or Mike Pence being the Republican nominee is not very high.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of now, Joe Biden has not made any definitive statements indicating that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in 2024. Historically, incumbents often seek re-election, and Biden has shown interest in running again. However, there are factors that could influence his decision, such as age, health, and political climate. Given that the question specifically asks for a definitive announcement, the probability of him making such a statement before the deadline is uncertain but seems relatively low, considering his current position. Therefore, while there is a possibility that he could announce he will not run, it does not appear to be the most likely outcome.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model, and (b) Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
(a) Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model: Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise. Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

(b) Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President: Resolves YES if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign does not make a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a Yes resolution, the absence of such a statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No. Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus. Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the likelihood of both events occurring, we need to evaluate each part of the question separately.

(a) Kamala Harris's odds of winning increasing according to Nate Silver's model: The prediction of her odds is contingent on a specific date and a threshold (greater than 46.6%). Given the dynamic nature of political polling and the fact that the election is still some time away, it is plausible that her odds could fluctuate based on various factors such as public opinion, campaign activity, and potential rival candidates. Without concrete data from Nate Silver's model as of the specified date, it's challenging to provide a precise probability, but I would estimate a moderate chance of her odds increasing, perhaps around 60%.

(b) Joe Biden's announcement regarding the Democratic nomination: Biden's decision-making is influenced by many factors, including political strategy and public sentiment. Historically, incumbent presidents or those with significant support tend to delay announcements about their candidacy until closer to the election. Given that Biden has not made any definitive statements about stepping down and considering the political landscape, it seems likely that he will not make such an announcement before the specified date. I would estimate a high probability of him not announcing his withdrawal, around 75%.

Now, combining these two probabilities to determine the likelihood of both events occurring together (using the product of probabilities, assuming independence):

Probability of (a) happening: 0.60 (60%)
Probability of (b) happening: 0.75 (75%)

Combined probability = 0.60 * 0.75 = 0.45 (45%).

Thus, while both events have reasonable chances of happening, the combined likelihood of both occurring is lower than either event happening individually.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, or (b) Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body: (a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive. If such a statement is not made by the deadline, this resolves as No. (b) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model? This resolves as Yes if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is greater than 46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves No otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of either event (a) or (b) occurring, we need to consider the current political landscape and trends. For (a), Joe Biden's announcement regarding not seeking the Democratic nomination is contingent on various factors, including his health, public opinion, and the political climate as the election approaches. Given that as of now, he has not indicated any intention to step down, and considering the typical behavior of incumbents seeking re-election, the likelihood of such an announcement seems low. However, unexpected events could change this, but they are difficult to predict. For (b), Kamala Harris's odds of winning the nomination can fluctuate based on various factors such as polling data, endorsements, and public sentiment. Nate Silver's model is influenced by these dynamics, and given the current political climate, it is reasonable to expect that her odds could increase if there are positive developments for her campaign or shifts in public opinion. Considering both scenarios, it seems more likely that Kamala Harris's odds of winning could increase over the next week than for Biden to announce he will not seek the nomination. Therefore, while the probability of either event occurring is not extremely high, the chances lean more towards the possibility of (b) happening.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has a historically strong performance in the Olympics, particularly in terms of winning Gold medals. In recent Olympic Games, including the Tokyo 2020 Olympics (held in 2021), the U.S. consistently outperformed other nations in Gold medal counts, often winning significantly more Golds than Silvers. Factors contributing to this trend include the depth of talent across various sports, investment in training and facilities, and a strong sports culture that encourages competition. Additionally, the U.S. Olympic Team has a wide range of events where they excel, which increases their chances of winning more Golds. Given these historical trends and the ongoing development of athletes, it is reasonable to predict that the U.S. will win more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

question.title: Will the USA both top the Olympic Medal Table and win as many or more Silver than Gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if both of the following occur:
(a) The United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:
1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

(b) The United States Olympic Team wins as many or more Silver medals than Gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

The question will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the likelihood of the USA topping the Olympic medal table while also winning as many or more Silver medals than Gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics, we need to consider several factors:

1. **Historical Performance**: The USA has a strong track record in the Olympics, often topping the medal table. In previous Olympics, they have consistently performed well across a wide range of sports, which bodes well for their chances in Paris.

2. **Team Composition**: The USA typically fields a large and talented team across many sports, which increases their chances of winning a significant number of medals. The depth of talent in sports like swimming, athletics, and gymnastics often leads to a high medal count.

3. **Silver vs. Gold Medals**: The requirement that the USA wins as many or more Silver medals than Gold medals adds a layer of complexity. Historically, the USA has often won more Gold medals than Silver. However, this can vary based on the performance of athletes in specific events. If the USA excels in events where Silver medals are more common (like team sports or certain relay events), this could be achievable.

4. **Competition**: Other countries, such as China and Russia, are also strong contenders and could challenge the USA's position at the top of the medal table. However, the USA's overall strength and depth typically give them an edge.

5. **Potential for Ambiguity**: The condition that the question will resolve ambiguously if the Olympics do not take place before 2027 is relevant. However, as of now, the Paris Olympics are scheduled to occur in 2024, so this condition does not currently apply.

Considering these factors, it seems likely that the USA could top the medal table, but the requirement for Silver medals to equal or exceed Gold medals introduces uncertainty. However, given the historical performance and depth of the USA team, I would estimate a reasonably high probability for this scenario.

question.title: Will either of the following occur at the Paris 2024 Olympics: (a) The USA wins more Gold than Silver medals (b) The USA tops the Olympic Medal Table?
question.body:
This question resolves YES if either of the following conditions are met:
(a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.
(b) The United States Olympic Team is the unique highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics, based on the medal table which orders countries by the number of Gold medals, then Silver medals, then Bronze medals. This question resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It resolves NO if neither condition is met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has a strong historical performance in the Olympics, consistently ranking at or near the top of the medal table. In recent Olympics, the USA has often won more Gold medals than Silver, and there is a high likelihood that they will continue this trend in Paris 2024. Given the depth of talent across various sports, it's reasonable to expect that the USA will be competitive enough to achieve both conditions outlined in the question. For the first condition, the USA typically excels in sports where Gold medals are plentiful, such as swimming, athletics, and gymnastics, which could easily lead to more Golds than Silvers. For the second condition, the USA has topped the medal table in many past Olympics, and given their resources, training, and athlete pool, it is plausible they will retain this position in 2024. Considering these factors, I estimate a high probability that at least one of the conditions will be met.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question revolves around the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which addresses the disqualification of individuals from holding office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. While there has been significant discussion and debate regarding Trump's eligibility under this provision, actual removal or blocking from state ballots involves a complex interplay of legal interpretations, state laws, and court rulings.

As of now, there are no definitive legal precedents that guarantee Trump's removal from any state ballot under Section 3. Legal challenges and political maneuvers are likely to arise, but the resolution of this question depends on official actions taken by state governments or courts by the specified date. Given the current political climate and the potential for legal battles, it seems unlikely that a definitive removal will occur by July 15, 2024. Therefore, while there may be attempts to block him from ballots, the probability of a successful and confirmed removal across any state is low.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Donald Trump will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Donald Trump will not be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

2. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has not been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. There must be no official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports confirming such a removal or block. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has not been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves positively.

The question will resolve as **No** if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the likelihood of both conditions being met for Donald Trump to be the Republican nominee and not being removed from the ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, we need to consider several factors.

1. **Republican Nomination**: As of now, Donald Trump is a prominent figure in the Republican party and has consistently led in polls among potential candidates for the 2024 presidential election. The Republican National Convention typically favors candidates with strong support from party members, and Trump has maintained a significant base. Given the current political landscape, it is plausible that he will be the nominee.

2. **Legal Challenges and Section 3 of the 14th Amendment**: Section 3 of the 14th Amendment has been a topic of discussion, especially regarding Trump's past actions and the events surrounding January 6, 2021. However, as of now, there has been no definitive legal ruling or widespread consensus that would lead to Trump's disqualification from ballots based on this section. Legal experts have debated its applicability, and while there may be attempts to challenge his candidacy, the actual removal from ballots would require substantial legal grounds and would likely involve lengthy court battles. Given the nature of the legal system, it is less likely that a definitive outcome will occur by July 15, 2024, especially considering the potential for appeals and delays.

Combining these insights, while there is uncertainty regarding the legal challenges he may face, the likelihood of Trump being the nominee and not being removed from the ballot seems relatively high, as there have been no significant developments indicating a strong possibility of disqualification as of the current date.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024? (b) Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following conditions is met:

(a) As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as "No". This question may consider new candidates added in the future. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To evaluate the likelihood of either condition (a) or (b) occurring, we need to analyze the political landscape and legal context surrounding Donald Trump as of now (October 2023) and projecting towards July 2024.

For condition (a), Section 3 of the 14th Amendment has been a topic of debate regarding its applicability to Trump due to the events surrounding January 6, 2021. However, there is currently no definitive legal precedent that guarantees he will be removed from the ballot in any state. Legal challenges are likely, and while there may be attempts to invoke this section, the actual removal or blocking would require a significant legal process and is uncertain at this point.

For condition (b), Donald Trump remains a highly influential figure within the Republican Party. As of now, he is leading many polls among Republican candidates for the 2024 Presidential nomination. Unless a significant shift occurs in the political landscape, such as a strong challenge from another candidate or a major scandal, it is very plausible that he will be the nominee.

Given these considerations, while condition (a) seems quite unlikely to occur, condition (b) has a high probability of happening. Therefore, the overall probability that either condition will occur by the specified date leans towards being more favorable towards condition (b).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To evaluate the probability of both conditions being met, we need to consider the current political landscape and the dynamics surrounding the Republican nomination for the 2024 Presidential Election.

(a) A member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee is quite plausible. Donald Trump has maintained a significant following within the Republican Party, and he has indicated his intention to run again. Other family members, while less likely, could also be considered, but the strongest candidate remains Donald Trump himself. Given his prominence and the loyalty of his base, I would assess this condition as having a high probability of occurring.

(b) As for Chris Christie, he has been a vocal critic of Donald Trump and has not garnered significant support within the party. His chances of becoming the nominee appear slim, especially with Trump as a strong contender. The Republican National Convention typically favors candidates who align more closely with the party's base, and Christie does not fit that mold as well as other potential candidates.

Considering these factors, it seems likely that a Trump family member will be the nominee while Chris Christie will not be. Both conditions are likely to be satisfied.
